title: Famous Authors & Literature
description: From Shakespeare to Hemingway — how well do you know the world's greatest books and authors?

questions.question: Who wrote the tragic love story 'Romeo and Juliet'?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare wrote 'Romeo and Juliet' around 1594-1596. It remains one of the most performed plays in the world and has inspired countless adaptations.

questions.question: In Shakespeare's 'Hamlet,' what is the famous opening line of Hamlet's most well-known soliloquy?
questions.explanation: 'To be, or not to be, that is the question' is perhaps the most famous line in all of English literature. The soliloquy explores themes of life, death, and existence.

questions.question: Charles Dickens wrote 'A Tale of Two Cities.' Which two cities does it refer to?
questions.explanation: 'A Tale of Two Cities' (1859) is set during the French Revolution. Its opening line — 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times' — is one of the most famous in literature.

questions.question: What was the real name of the American author known as Mark Twain?
questions.explanation: Samuel Langhorne Clemens adopted the pen name Mark Twain, a riverboat term meaning 'two fathoms deep.' He wrote 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer' and 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.'

questions.question: Which novel by Jane Austen begins with the line 'It is a truth universally acknowledged'?
questions.explanation: 'Pride and Prejudice' (1813) opens with one of the most iconic sentences in English literature. Austen completed the novel when she was just 21 years old.

questions.question: Ernest Hemingway wrote which of these novels?
options: The Old Man and the Sea
questions.explanation: 'The Old Man and the Sea' (1952) tells the story of an aging Cuban fisherman. It won the Pulitzer Prize in 1953 and helped Hemingway win the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954.

questions.question: F. Scott Fitzgerald is best known for writing which classic American novel?
questions.explanation: 'The Great Gatsby' (1925) captures the glamour and emptiness of the Jazz Age. Though it received mixed reviews initially, it is now considered one of the greatest American novels.

questions.question: Who wrote the classic novel 'To Kill a Mockingbird'?
questions.explanation: Harper Lee published 'To Kill a Mockingbird' in 1960. Set in the American South, it addresses racial injustice and won the Pulitzer Prize. Lee published only one other novel in her lifetime.

questions.question: J.R.R. Tolkien is the author of which fantasy epic?
questions.explanation: Tolkien published 'The Lord of the Rings' in three volumes between 1954 and 1955. He created entire languages for the world of Middle-earth, drawing on his expertise as a linguistics professor at Oxford.

questions.question: Agatha Christie holds the Guinness World Record for being the best-selling what?
questions.explanation: Agatha Christie is the best-selling fiction writer of all time, with over 2 billion copies sold worldwide. She created the beloved detectives Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple.

questions.question: Which poem by Edgar Allan Poe features a talking bird that repeats 'Nevermore'?
questions.explanation: 'The Raven' was published in 1845 and made Poe a household name. The poem's dark, melodic style and haunting refrain of 'Nevermore' made it an instant sensation.

questions.question: Emily Brontë wrote which classic novel set on the Yorkshire moors?
questions.explanation: 'Wuthering Heights' (1847) was Emily Brontë's only novel. It was published under the pen name Ellis Bell and tells the passionate, turbulent story of Heathcliff and Catherine.

questions.question: The ancient Greek poet Homer is credited with writing 'The Odyssey.' What is it about?
options: The creation of the Greek gods
Odysseus's long journey home after the Trojan War
questions.explanation: 'The Odyssey' follows the hero Odysseus on his 10-year journey home after the Trojan War. It's one of the oldest works of Western literature, composed around the 8th century BC.

questions.question: Who wrote the novel 'Moby Dick' about an obsessive hunt for a white whale?
questions.explanation: Herman Melville published 'Moby Dick' in 1851. It was a commercial failure during his lifetime but is now considered one of the greatest American novels ever written.

questions.question: Who wrote the dystopian novel '1984,' which introduced concepts like 'Big Brother' and 'thoughtcrime'?
questions.explanation: George Orwell published '1984' in 1949, depicting a totalitarian society under constant surveillance. The novel's terms like 'Big Brother' and 'Orwellian' have become part of everyday language.
